name: Henry I - Youngest Son of the Conqueror Quiz | People | 15 Questions

questions.text: How many elder brothers did Henry I have when he was born in 1069?
questions.explanation:
3.

	The eldest brother was Robert who became Duke of Normandy. The second brother was Richard who was killed in a hunting accident in about 1075. The third brother was William who became William II known as William Rufus.

questions.text: What was the name of Henry I's mother?
questions.explanation:
Matilda of Flanders.

	Adela was Henry I's sister who married Stephen of Blois, the father of the future King Stephen. Constance was another sister who married the Duke of Brittany and Sybilla was Henry I's sister-in-law. She is the one that married Robert, his eldest brother.

questions.text: Why was Henry I given the nickname "Henry Beauclerc"?
questions.correct: It was because he could write.
options: It was because of his handsome appearance.
It was because he was a friend to the Church.
It was because he was a good horseman.
questions.explanation:
It was because he could write.

	Henry was an unusual monarch in that he didn't have to rely totally upon church educated clerks to transact all his business without him being able to check it.

questions.text: What was the name that was taken after her marriage by Henry I's first wife?
questions.explanation:
Matilda.

	Matilda was thus the name of his mother - Matilda of Flanders, the name of his wife - Matilda of Scotland who was previously called Edith, and the name of his daughter - Matilda the Empress of Germany.

questions.text: Henry's first wife is considered important for which of the following reasons?
questions.correct: She was descended from the Saxon English royal family.
options: She brought a huge dowry as part of her wedding settlement.
She managed to bear Henry several sons.
She was closely related to the man who was the Pope.
questions.explanation:
She was descended from the Saxon English royal family.

	Matilda was the daughter of Malcolm III of Scotland and St. Margaret of the English Royal Line. Thus her line can be traced back to Edmund Ironside and thus ultimately to King Alfred. This meant that the children that Henry I and Matilda had would unite the Saxon and Norman royal blood.

questions.text: In which county of England was Henry I born?
questions.explanation:
Yorkshire.

	He was born in September 1068 at Selby in Yorkshire. He died at St.Denis Le Fermont near Gisors on the 1st of December, 1135. His death is often attributed to eating too many eels. His body was buried in Reading Abbey.

questions.text: What was the first action that Henry took when he heard of the death of his brother, King William II?
questions.correct: He went to Winchester to demand the crown and the other royal treasures.
options: He ordered  his eldest  brother to be locked in the Tower of London.
He went to London to be prepared to be crowned as King.
He organised a hunt for those he believed had killed his brother.
questions.explanation:
He went to Winchester to demand the crown and the other royal treasures.

	The treasurer, William de Bretevil, at first  refused to admit Henry to Winchester and he reminded him that his elder brothers Robert and William had signed a treaty each making the other the heir to the kingdoms of Normandy and England if they died first. Under threat of death the treasurer finally handed over the keys.

questions.text: Where was Henry I crowned King of England?
questions.explanation:
Westminster Abbey.

	The ceremony took place on the 5th August, 1100, only three days after his brother William's death. Robert, his other brother, was still on his way back from the Crusade to the Holy Land.

questions.text: What part did Robert de Belleme, the Earl of Shrewsbury, play in the dispute between the two brothers Henry I and Robert?
questions.correct: He assisted the invasion of England that was made on behalf of Robert.
options: He supported Robert and stayed in Normandy to rule there while Robert invaded.
He remained loyal to Henry and fought Robert's invasion.
He was loyal to Henry and defeated the Scots at York.
questions.explanation:
He assisted the invasion of England that was made on behalf of Robert.

	Henry had ensured that the Scots would not invade by marrying King Malcolm's daughter. Robert de Belleme was caught and exiled to Normandy. Later he was taken in battle and had to spend the rest of his life in imprisonment.

questions.text: Henry I's son and heir was married to the daughter of which person?
questions.explanation:
Count Fulk of Anjou.

	Henry's aim was to unite the adjacent territories of Normandy and Anjou. Unfortunately his son was drowned in the tragedy of "The White Ship" in the English Channel. Later Henry's daughter, Matilda, was married to Geoffrey of Anjou.

questions.text: What was the name of Henry I's only legitimate son who was killed in the tragedy of "The White Ship"?
questions.explanation:
William.

	Some reports suggest that the tragedy happened because everyone on board the ship was drunk. The only survivor was a butcher who reputedly told this story to the King.

questions.text: What part did Adelicia, daughter of the Duke of Lower Lorraine, play in Henry I's life?
options: She was one of his mistresses.
She was married to one of his illegitimate sons.
She brought a charge of rape against him before the Pope.
questions.explanation:
She was his second wife.

	Adelicia (sometimes spelled Adeliza) married Henry on 29th January, 1122 in Westminster Abbey. However, she remained childless throughout their marriage. After Henry's death she married the Earl of Arundel.

questions.text: What happened at the Battle of Tinchebrai in 1106?
questions.correct: Henry defeated Robert and became Duke of Normandy as well as King of England.
options: Neither side won but Robert agreed to let Henry remain King of England.
Henry won the battle and had his brother executed.
Henry won the battle and let his brother go back to the Holy Land.
questions.explanation:
Henry defeated Robert and became Duke of Normandy as well as King of England.

	The battle was decisive. Henry was finally undisputed as King of England and his brother Robert was locked up for all the remaining years of his life. Henry's life did not become easier because he now had to defend Normandy as well as England.

questions.text: What was the name of leading churchman with whom Henry I had a protracted dispute?
questions.explanation:
Anselm.

	Henry had little time for the Church and was said to have chosen his chaplain on account of the rapid speed at which he said the mass. Henry loved money and was responsible for the keeping of the accounts which became known as the Exchequer.

questions.text: How many illegitimate children was Henry I known to have fathered?
questions.explanation:
More than 20.

	It is said that he fathered 26 acknowledged illegitimate children. There may have been more ! However, he had only two legitimate children - William, who died in the White Ship and Matilda, the Empress whose second marriage to Geoffrey of Anjou was deeply unpopular in England. The Norman barons were not keen on the idea of a female monarch and hence we have the disputed succession between Stephen, Henry's nephew, and Matilda, his only remaining legitimate child.
